body: Last week was the worst in Bill Casey's 27-year career in the New York City school system. Today, things get worse. Today, Mr. Casey, the superintendent of Community School Board 15 in southeastern Brooklyn, will have to decide how many teachers, school aides, paraprofessionals and other employees in his district will lose their jobs to meet city
title: Painful Task: Meeting Goal To Cut Costs For Schools

body: LEAD: David and Toni small have just spent $50,000 to improve their home in Lake Hopatcong, N.J. The updated kitchen has new oak cabinets, a new floor of Mexican tiles, new pale yellow countertops and new appliances. The terrace and stone steps leading from the house to the shore of the lake have been regrouted and the 10-room house is wearing a
title: Residential Remodeling Making Gains

body: LEAD: Staten Island residents yesterday began separating most kinds of plastic from their garbage, in the latest expansion of New York City's mandatory recycling program. Plastic products and packaging make up a growing part of municipal waste. The Federal Government estimates that such trash will increase by 50 percent in the next 10 years. Many
title: In Its Latest Recycling Effort, S.I. Targets Plastic

body: LEAD: Drawing on the architectural tradition of the mews - 19th-century stables or carriage houses grouped around a courtyard - a developer in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn is completing three small houses that are bigger than many apartments but smaller than most single-family homes. title: Postings: Carroll Gardens Condos; Brooklyn Mews

body: LEAD: New York City's property-tax system, which has been criticized for a decade for placing a heavier burden on less-affluent homeowners than on wealthier ones, appears to have grown more inequitable. body: LEAD: CHICKEN SOUP SEEMS TO BELONG to New York. It is a curative, a panacea, a culinary medium. Its aroma rushes from the doors of Jewish delis and waves like steamy ribbons behind the bicycles that deliver Chinese food throughout the city. The scent of chicken soup lingers over kitchen stoops in the Italian section of Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn,
title: FOOD; IT CURES WHAT AILS

body: LEAD: Frank X. Gargiulo, a former member of the New York City Civil Service Commission, died Thursday of a brain tumor at the St. Rose of Lima Home in Manhattan. He was 60 years old and lived in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn. Frank X. Gargiulo, a former member of the New York City Civil Service Commission, died Thursday of a brain tumor
title: Frank X. Gargiulo, 60, Of Civil Service Panel
